content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Clash seems difficult but it's simple. I like it, nice job.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like how this problem at first looks like a super difficult problem, but after some trials it is actually trivial to implement.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great clash!

Just a personal think I might just be bad at reading and understanding but it'll probably be helpful if you just bold or emphasize the fact that they are finding the maximum sum.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
I don't understand the usefulness of declaring a vector in the given solution but otherwise it's flowing

Good puzzle. It first tricks into thinking that Sum(a_i-1) may be unachievable in some cases leading to an overcomplicated solution. However, Sum(a_i-1) is achievable when x=lcf(a_1, ..., a_n)-1, which makes computing the answer easier. Nice clash!

In the example explanation, you could have used 29 instead of 509.
Additionally, n is not strictly necessary for the solution.

Short solution in ruby (probably not the shortest):

n=gets.to_i
p gets.split().sum(&:to_i)-n

Alternatively:

gets
r=gets.split().map(&:to_i)
p r.sum-r.count

Basically, sum of each element (minus one) in the array or the sum of the array minus the amount of elements in the array.

It would be far harder to find x for all the cases; maybe consider that as a puzzle aswell?
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

I think you made a typo here, "As a friend on Sam,"
It should be "As a friend of Sam,"

I like the question. The code itself is simple once you understood the logic, so definitely good for fastest and shorts

le puzzle est bien mais on peut croire à tort qu'il faut calculer x ce qui finalement n'est pas le cas, x n'a aucune raison d'exister à moins que je ne me trompe, sinon pour l'exécution, je n'ai pas relevé de problèmes

the puzzle is good but we can mistakenly believe that we need to calculate 'x' but really is not the case, x has no reason to exist unless I am mistaken.
For the execution, I did not find any problems

Les données reçues font penser que le puzzle est compliqué et qu'il faut connaître des mathématique alors qu'en réalité c'est très simple

The data received makes you think the puzzle is complicated and you have to know some mathematics when in reality it is very simple to solve

The fact that the statement asks twice to "find a positive integer" is quite misleading as we do not actually need to find this integer.
I would rephrase the statement as follows:

"If you are provided n integers, a_i (1 <= i <= n), what is the maximal sum you can obtain by choosing a single positive integer and adding the modulo of this integer to each a_i?

More formally, what is the maximal value of 
x MOD a_1 + x MOD a_2 + x MOD a_3 + ... + x MOD a_(n-1) + x MOD a_n
that can be obtained by judiciously choosing the value of the positive integer x."

Goal section
* Please fix the typo "postive".

* The definition of "positive integer" may be removed.

Stub generator
* Please use "loop" instead of providing a string whenever possible e.g. splitting a string is not the focus of a puzzle.

Thanks.

Fixed Typo.

Although the definition is kinda known universally among players, I would say adding a definition wouldn't affect the readability a lot, and it's better to make it clear than assuming people know.

For the stub generator, I have no idea how to do it.
I used 

read n:int
loop n read x:int

but it failed.

If "positive integer" needs to be defined in one contribution, does that mean it has to be defined in EVERY contribution?

When I read "*positive integer", I think "is there something special about it?" And after I read the definition, the answer is "no". And spending a few more seconds on that...

And oh sorry, it should be "loopline" in your case.
